citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On December 17, 2025, a primary transport enclosure containing an adult terrier was inspected in the animal holding area
prior to being loaded on an aircraft at San Diego International Airport. The transport enclosure did not have any labels
indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure. Failure to appropriately mark primary enclosures used in transport
may result in delayed response in the event of an emergency or improper care of animals when handling or moving the
enclosure.
When an enclosure is not permanently affixed to the transport conveyance, it must be clearly marked with arrows or some
other labeling indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure.

On December 17, 2025, a primary transport enclosure containing an adult terrier was inspected in the animal holding area
prior to being loaded onto an aircraft at San Diego International Airport enroute to Toronto, Canada. Upon inspection the
dog appeared to be in good health and securely contained within its primary enclosure, however there was no food or
water dish affixed to the carrier. Transporting animals without food or water receptacles can compromise the carrier's
ability to ensure adequate food and water is provided for the animal’s health and well-being while transported. Failure to
provide adequate food and water may be distressful and can have serious impacts on the health and well-being of the
dog.
Carriers must not accept a dog for transport without food and water receptacles securely attached inside the primary
enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be filled from outside the enclosure without opening the door.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.15(a)(6) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On December 17, 2025, a primary transport enclosure containing an adult terrier was inspected in the animal holding area 
prior to being loaded on an aircraft at San Diego International Airport. The transport enclosure did not have any labels 
indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure. Failure to appropriately mark primary enclosures used in transport 
may result in delayed response in the event of an emergency or improper care of animals when handling or moving the 
enclosure.  
 
When an enclosure is not permanently affixed to the transport conveyance, it must be clearly marked with arrows or some 
other labeling indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure. 
3.17(c) 
   
Food and water requirements. 
On December 17, 2025, a primary transport enclosure containing an adult terrier was inspected in the animal holding area 
prior to being loaded onto an aircraft at San Diego International Airport enroute to Toronto, Canada. Upon inspection the 
dog appeared to be in good health and securely contained within its primary enclosure, however there was no food or 
water dish affixed to the carrier. Transporting animals without food or water receptacles can compromise the carrier's 
ability to ensure adequate food and water is provided for the animal’s health and well-being while transported. Failure to 
provide adequate food and water may be distressful and can have serious impacts on the health and well-being of the 
dog. 
 
Carriers must not accept a dog for transport without food and water receptacles securely attached inside the primary 
enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be filled from outside the enclosure without opening the door. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
